children.value: A tutorial to evolve markdown documents and notebooks into structured data
Suppose we have a complicated function

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: , made of natural logs and arctangents or whatever. Not friendly to deal with. We could reasonably ask the question: if there is another function

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: that has the same value as

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
x=x0x=x_0x=x0​

children.value: , and the same value of the first derivative (so the value of

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: is changing just as rapidly as

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
x=x0x=x_0x=x0​

children.value: ), and the same value of the second derivative (so the rate of change of the rate of change of

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)
f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: ), and the same value of the third derivative, and the same value of the fourth derivative, etc., onwards to the infinitieth derivative... well, that sounds like we effectively have the same functional behavior for both

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: . So what do we think of

children.html: f^(x)=f(x0)+f′(x0)(x−x0)+12!f′′(x0)(x−x0)2+13!f′′(x0)(x−x0)3+⋯+1N!f(N)(x0)(x−x0)N\hat{f}(x) = f(x_0)+ f'(x_0)(x-x_0) + \frac{1}{2!}f''(x_0)(x-x_0)^2 + \frac{1}{3!}f''(x_0)(x-x_0)^3 + \dots + \frac{1}{N!}f^{(N)}(x_0)(x-x_0)^Nf^​(x)=f(x0​)+f′(x0​)(x−x0​)+2!1​f′′(x0​)(x−x0​)2+3!1​f′′(x0​)(x−x0​)3+⋯+N!1​f(N)(x0​)(x−x0​)N
x=x0x=x_0x=x0​

children.value: , the above function matches the value

children.html: f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​)

children.value: . Take the first derivative and evaluate at

children.html: x=x0x=x_0x=x0​
f^′(x0)=f′(x0)\hat{f}'(x_0)=f'(x_0)f^​′(x0​)=f′(x0​)

children.value: . On and on for all derivatives. This polynomial

children.html: f^′(x)=f′(x0)(x−x0)+12!f′′(x0)(x−x0)2+13!f′′(x0)(x−x0)3+⋯+1N!f(N)(x0)(x−x0)N\hat{f}'(x) = f'(x_0)(x-x_0) + \frac{1}{2!}f''(x_0)(x-x_0)^2 + \frac{1}{3!}f''(x_0)(x-x_0)^3 + \dots + \frac{1}{N!}f^{(N)}(x_0)(x-x_0)^Nf^​′(x)=f′(x0​)(x−x0​)+2!1​f′′(x0​)(x−x0​)2+3!1​f′′(x0​)(x−x0​)3+⋯+N!1​f(N)(x0​)(x−x0​)N

children.value: The most important lesson we learn from Taylor Series is how to approximate a function as a line, at least “near” to a point. Notice that in the “full” Taylor Series

children.html: x+4x+4x+4
